A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual is asked to answer all questions. Each of these experiences may be different for each person who answers them.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and nursing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.
A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire for pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer will necessarily have all the experiences that others may have had. Some of you may have had experiences which are not relevant to your experience; others may have important aspects of your life which you do not want to answer. You should not feel obliged to answer all questions.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1971, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
They thought it was a very good idea, so it was better for my health in England than a damp climate.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
Friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
First class by boat, last class by train, then by horseback to Fort Macleod.

14. What incidents of the journey most do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
To the Appalachees by horseback.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
At my friend Mrs. Elkinston at Fort Macleod.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
I worked at home in England. I worked at Fort Macleod.
